rage.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: a strong feeling of uncontrollable anger
rage.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Sobbing with rage, Carol was taken to the hospital.
Richens was 17 when he flew into a rage and stabbed another teenager.
Just then, she heard Mr Evan’s bellow of rage.
His face was red with rage.
Forester stared at his car, trembling with rage.
Animal rights supporters were incandescent with rage.
Sam became quite frightening when he was in a rage.

rage.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: to feel very angry about something and show this in the way you behave or speak
rage.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: ‘How was I to know!’ Jenny raged.
He was sorry he had raged at her earlier.
rage.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if something such as a battle, a disagreement, or a storm rages, it continues with great violence or strong emotions
rage.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Civil war has been raging in the country for years.
A debate is raging about what form pensions should take.
rage.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: if a fire or illness rages, it spreads fast and is hard to control
rage.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: The fire raged for twelve hours and fifteen people died.
A great cholera epidemic raged across Europe in 1831.
rage.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: to have fun with a group of people in a wild and uncontrolled way
rage.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: We couldn’t wait to go out and rage.
rage.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a feeling of extreme, uncontrollable anger
